text:
I’m interviewing Content Marketers to fill an open position, and I’m coming to the point where I’ve got a few good candidates but I want to know what their writing is _really_ like. Sure they all have a portfolio but I don’t know how long that really took them, and if others were involved etc. As a hiring manager, how do you *test* their ability to craft good content, within X amount of time? I’ve thought about asking them to do a paid assignment, and say ask them to be available at say time `X` for the assignment, and tell them to hand in the assignment at `X+4` so I know this is what the result is after `4 hours.` 4 hours is just an example, the time required/given depends on the assignment of course.

Curious to hear your approach to this. Thanks in advance!

Curious to hear your approach to this. Thanks in advance!

text:
Hi <@U014PRHQUQ2>, I once interviewed for a position like that and I had a two-hour window to submit a writing sample on a given topic. Just before the interview happened, I had a nasty stomach ache and spent the two hours on the toilet. They never let me try again because they thought I was lying. Not fun.
Check out their portfolio and chat with their previous employers, they’ll have a word or two to say about their ability to meet deadlines. As for your own test, give them a paid test assignment which is meaningful (as in it actually relates to what they will do) and cap it at 1-2 days. Once again, in my own experience, if they really wanted to find help for that quick of a turnaround time, they would struggle finding a good writer to do it instead of them. In any case, you’ll know very soon after hiring them what they’re all about.

Once again, in my own experience, if they really wanted to find help for that quick of a turnaround time, they would struggle finding a good writer to do it instead of them. In any case, you’ll know very soon after hiring them what they’re all about.

text:
I recently hired someone on my team. We had a 3-part paid assignment where writing an article was one of the parts. The entire assignment was capped at 5 days after which we wouldn't be accepting it (unless there are special circumstances).

Also, they needed to write the outline of the post first followed by the post. That way I could get a hint of how they think.  

I'm not sure if that answers your question. We can get on a call if that helps!

text:
I've hired a few content managers/copywriters to my team and I would never give them "X hours" for writing. For me, it's a creative task - it takes research, takes time and takes creativity you simply may not have. As long as the deadlines are met, I'm happy. When I'm recruiting, I'm giving a deadline. It's met = I'm happy.

In the last few days I had to write two articles - similar length and topic. One of them took me 2 hours (such a flow), the second one took me 10-12h because it just wasn't my day and I had a lot of small chores to do, but I still submitted content within deadlines.

So I'd recommend testing it via deadlines, not hours, and that's how it works perfectly with my team :slightly_smiling_face:

Thank you - this is how it should be. Give your experts a deadline and get out of their way so they can get it done in a way that suits their style and workflow.

Sometimes inspiration doesn't come until the 11th hour, during which they can bang out the entire 2000-word article in a flash.

text: Well, but when content marketers don't do research? :slightly_smiling_face: It's an integral part of CM work in my opinion. There are so many factors contributing to "time" of writing that "hours" simply won't work and will put a lot of pressure on the project. I think I tried once with my team and Clockify and that didn't work out, I was the one to call it off :slightly_smiling_face: Good luck whatever you decide!

text: agreed. research is an integral part of any writing task, especially if the candidates aren't from your industry. also keep in mind that these candidates may not have the time available in the day to actually do your assignment within the time frame allotted if they have full time jobs or other commitments. can you imagine trying to do a writing assignment at your full time job? they're likely to get caught and reprimanded for it.

text: Kind of a weird question but trying my luck here: my CEO has asked me how my SEO budget should increase and if I can give a clear formula that can justify an increase in investment. (We’ve got some extra cash flow that he is deciding where to invest in.) Today our SEO budget is spent on 1) paying our content agency (Animalz :slightly_smiling_face: ) and 2) a freelancer who helps me get backlinks and newsletter swaps. Our SEO performance is promising (all greens, rather steep lines going up for SEO traffic, rankings, keywords, referring domains, etc.) He’s generally happy and feels we should put more money. But by how much? I suggested increasing by 50% every quarter and he asked “why 50%? why not 70%? 200%?” and I honestly don’t have an answer. He’s thrown out related questions like “how much would it cost for us to rank #1 for these 3 selected keywords” which again I couldn’t answer. Anyone here has any experience dealing with this kind of SEO related questions and have some insights you can share? Thank you so much in advance :pray:

elements.text: Kind of a weird question but trying my luck here: my CEO has asked me how my SEO budget should increase and if I can give a clear formula that can justify an increase in investment. He’s thrown out related questions like “how much would it cost for us to rank #1 for these 3 selected keywords” which again I couldn’t answer. Anyone here has any experience dealing with this kind of SEO related questions and have some insights you can share? Thank you so much in advance

text: LOVE these kinds of questions from CEOs.

elements.text: LOVE these kinds of questions from CEOs.

text: I think the “cost to rank” shows a misunderstanding of SEO where you can definitely do some education. Sure, there’s a cost (content, links, etc.) but that cost is ongoing and can’t be bought overnight.

elements.text: I think the “cost to rank” shows a misunderstanding of SEO where you can definitely do some education. Sure, there’s a cost (content, links, etc.) but that cost is ongoing and can’t be bought overnight.

text: You can definitely do the math by looking at the top ranking articles in Ahrefs/SEMrush and see how many links to that page, do the math of how many links you’d need either to buy or pay somebody to do outreach for. You’ll also have to look at the link velocity of the pages you’re competing against. Sure, the top page has 100 referring domains today, but by the time you can get 100 to your page, they may have earned another 75 just by ranking tops and getting links (or building themselves).

text: If I were you, I’d reframe the conversation around what the SEO does for the business, versus it in a goal in and of itself.

elements.text: If I were you, I’d reframe the conversation around what the SEO does for the business, versus it in a goal in and of itself.

text:
Your CEO has to understand what ranking #1 is going to mean in terms of traffic, into leads, into conversions, etc.

Then, let that number guide the budget. If an article could convert X% of Y visitors. Then we know we’ll close another % of that at a specific LTV, we know what whether that article can do that for us, or whether it might take 6 months to ramp up and we won’t see an ROI for another 6 after that.

text:
Hey <@U01K0BWEQD6>! Great question :slightly_smiling_face:

I think because we’re operating on 2 week sprints, it makes it easier to adjust especially in the case that someone gets sick. However when it comes to vacation/holidays which allow us to prepare/plan in advance, that gets taken into consideration during sprint planning. So, if we know someone will be gone for half the sprint (1 week), the work they commit to for that sprint is a weeks worth of work vs. 2.

When it comes to the bigger holidays (I.e. we have a 2-3 week winter shut down), we give everyone that time off, but assign 2 work days worth of holiday homework. So, this could be write 2 blogs, clean up/optimize ads, etc.

Hope that clarifies!

elements.text: Hey

So, if we know someone will be gone for half the sprint (1 week), the work they commit to for that sprint is a weeks worth of work vs. 2.

When it comes to the bigger holidays (I.e. we have a 2-3 week winter shut down), we give everyone that time off, but assign 2 work days worth of holiday homework. So, this could be write 2 blogs, clean up/optimize ads, etc.

Hope that clarifies!

text:
You should invest in your technical SEO.

Right now your page performance score is a 50, and while your First contentful paint score is fast (0.7%) your total blocking time and time to interactive is on the higher side.

There are some pretty solid opportunities you have that could shave off ~1 second of your loading time, which has shown to improve conversions and reduce bounce rates among other things.

What’s important to stress to the CEO in this case is that SEO isn’t just about keywords, and that an investment in the technical side of SEO can improve your overall performance from a ranking, revenue, and user experience perspective.

How do you navigate that?

text:
Hopefully hard numbers/ROI types can wrap their heads around probabilities, yeah?

Using the techniques above in this thread, I figure it's not a mathematical impossibility to frame stuff up the same way you'd approach an investment in a financial instrument. What's the ROI on ranking #1 vs #2?

Depends... but across 5 different reports from credible sources A thru E, you can observe a traffic increase of anywhere between X% and Y%. For us, that's $X to $Y in additional revenue. Cost for us to rank #1? 75% chance it will be less than Y, 50% less than $X. Math that out to ROI probabilities.

Present the final calculations, be ready to show work.

This concludes my CEO-SEO conversation fantasy :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
To use a completely different example, when an executive has asked about direct conversions from a blog page, I’ve asked, “when was the last time you read a blog and said, ’OH! I have to buy this thing!”

Then explain the difference between blog pages and transactional pages.

Setting that context of putting them in the visitor’s shoes, then tying that to the metrics that show improved rankings and Google’s guidelines, has been pretty powerful.

text:
Yep, the thing I also try to stress (because I’ve been in long-cycle B2B) is to look out for increases in return visitors and direct.

A lot of SEO is about casting the wide net, but those return visits (IMO) are absolutely critical for long-cycle B2B.

text:
At my company we always do a writing test — draft of a full blog article according to our standards, in about a 4-5 day time frame. Frustrations with that:
• I have been in the position where applicants were writing the same blog post as I was (we don’t typically publish writing test blogs), which felt rather futile 
• It seems to me that a paid test - with option to publish if the piece were good, even if that person were not hired, would be a great way to build goodwill among applicants. 
• But, that means you can’t just give it to everyone… we often put the writing test very early in the process to go ahead and weed out people who aren’t serious or who aren’t good writers. I don’t love this approach, but YMMV

elements.text: At my company we always do a writing test — draft of a full blog article according to our standards, in about a 4-5 day time frame. Frustrations with that:
I have been in the position where applicants were writing the same blog post as I was (we don’t typically publish writing test blogs), which felt rather futile
It seems to me that a paid test - with option to publish if the piece were good, even if that person were not hired, would be a great way to build goodwill among applicants.

But, that means you can’t just give it to everyone… we often put the writing test very early in the process to go ahead and weed out people who aren’t serious or who aren’t good writers. I don’t love this approach, but YMMV

text:
I've been trying to rank for some low-volume keywords like "freelance B2B writer".

I'm not there yet. But I'm curious if it's worth ranking for such keywords?

Would it actually get me more leads for my freelance business?

I recently read your post <@UUXMCJQ15> about trophy keywords and would be happy to  hear your thoughts too.

elements.text:
I've been trying to rank for some low-volume keywords like "freelance B2B writer".

I'm not there yet. But I'm curious if it's worth ranking for such keywords?

Would it actually get me more leads for my freelance business?

I recently read your post
about trophy keywords and would be happy to  hear your thoughts too.

text: Low volume is okay, but what is the keyword difficulty? If it’s incredibly high (I would say anything higher than 30 in Ahrefs would be tough), it may not be worth it. Also, make sure to check the nature of the keyword, i.e. whether it is transactional or not. Is it used by other writers to look for open roles or by business owners/managers looking to hire a writer, or something else? Once you know these two, you’ll know if it’s worth pursuing this keyword or not

text: Hi Steven, I've been on the writing end of a few test assignments and have had a few thoughts on them. I find that most quality content takes time to create and the best writers typically don't do the entire thing in one sitting (outline, draft, editing). Most decent writers can Google around for an hour or two researching a topic and come up with a decent post, but if you want something really stellar, they probably need a little more time (and leeway). For example, I've done test pieces where I reached out to experts for quotes to include in the post. However, this sort of "above and beyond" work isn't possible with a short deadline and won't allow a really talented content marketer to shine through. Also, I'm not sure if this is for a freelance position or full time, but if it's freelance, remember that most freelancers don't want a job because they appreciate time flexibility. So you might lose the best applicants by having a timeframe. Just a thought to keep in mind!

elements.text: Hi Steven, I've been on the writing end of a few test assignments and have had a few thoughts on them. I find that most quality content takes time to create and the best writers typically don't do the entire thing in one sitting (outline, draft, editing). Most decent writers can Google around for an hour or two researching a topic and come up with a decent post, but if you want something really stellar, they probably need a little more time (and leeway). For example, I've done test pieces where I reached out to experts for quotes to include in the post. However, this sort of "above and beyond" work isn't possible with a short deadline and won't allow a really talented content marketer to shine through. Also, I'm not sure if this is for a freelance position or full time, but if it's freelance, remember that most freelancers don't want a job because they appreciate time flexibility. So you might lose the best applicants by having a timeframe. Just a thought to keep in mind!

text: Love Brendan's response! Curious if your end goal is to just increase freelance writing clients? I've been going through the journey myself and found that my current biggest clients actually reached out to me organically after seeing my byline on some fairly big content marketing websites. So I'd definitely take Brendan's response and get your website going, but also consider doing guest posts for major content marketing blogs- not so much for the links but more for the byline. Specifically, I got a guest post on the Content Marketing Institute- so that might be a great place to start. Just make sure that what you write is something really creative and takes a unique angle on current issues in the space. For example, I heard everyone saying that original research is an amazing way to generate links, leads, traffic, etc. But when I asked people how to do it, everyone just said to hire someone to help. As I was operating on a shoestring budget, I wanted to learn how to create original data on a shoestring budget. So I did a roundup of industry experts and asked for examples of posts they gathered data for that cost under $50... and then wrote a post on it.

Just make sure that what you write is something really creative and takes a unique angle on current issues in the space. For example, I heard everyone saying that original research is an amazing way to generate links, leads, traffic, etc. But when I asked people how to do it, everyone just said to hire someone to help. As I was operating on a shoestring budget, I wanted to learn how to create original data on a shoestring budget. text:
Hi all,
Do you have any advice or experience that you can share on interviewing customers? I'm going to do some interviews in the next few weeks to discover how our customers are using our product, similar to a customer discovery interview but for existing customers.
I know some ground rules like 'don't assume anything', and 'ask only about the present and the past', but I'd love to hear what I should expect in a real interview:grinning:
Thanks in advance!

elements.text:
Hi all,
Do you have any advice or experience that you can share on interviewing customers? I'm going to do some interviews in the next few weeks to discover how our customers are using our product, similar to a customer discovery interview but for existing customers.
I know some ground rules like 'don't assume anything', and 'ask only about the present and the past', but I'd love to hear what I should expect in a real interview
Thanks in advance!
